characters: THE WALL IN FRONT OF BARNEY'S PROPERTY 201

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRED FLINTSTONE, archetypical Everyman, sits atop his faithful heavy-equipment dinosaur, cranking the winch that makes the mighty beast rip and tear into the quarry wall.

dialogues.speaker: THE QUARRY FOREMAN
dialogues.text: looks down at his wristwatch. Well... actually, it's a wrist sundial. And it's magic time... quittin' time... Millerock time! Now the foreman turns from his watch to a steam whistle bird, and yanks its tail. The BIRD SQUAWKS the end of the workday --

dialogues.speaker: YABBA DABBA DO
dialogues.text: Fred happily discards his hard hat, leaps out of the canvas-roofed cab on the dino's back, slides down the tail and bounces right into the seat of his stone and timber car! He gets up to a running start with the only motor (his feet), slows to allow a "time clock" dinosaur to punch his stone timecard, and then he's trotting back up to speed and out of the gate! MUSIC comes UP and

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "Flintstones, Meet the Flintstones, They're a modern Stone age fam-i-ly --' -- And so forth, as for the first time in "his-tor-y" we see the Flintstones' OPENING CREDITS live!

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON A MAILBOX
dialogues.text: reading "FLINTSTONE." We WIDEN as Fred SKIDS to a halt in the driveway of his three-bedroom ranch cave. A moment later, WILMA and PEBBLES run out -- both looking just like they should -- and get into the car. A beat behind them are the Flintstone pets, Dino and the saber-toothed cat. Fred pauses, looks around... HONKS his HORN... BARNEY, BETTY and BAM-BAM come out of the neighboring house, hop in! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred's feet slap on the street as the car starts up --

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "From the Town of Bedrock They're a page right | Out of his-tor-y --

dialogues.speaker: DRIVE-IN MOVIE THEATRE
dialogues.text: Fred and company pull in. He takes a giant sea shell "speaker" off of its wooden stand and hooks it to his car door. He leans over, puts his arm around Wilma. (In the back seat, Dino pops his head up, tearing through the canvas top.) Dino picks up Pebbles and Bam-Bam and puts them on his head for a better view. CAMERA ZOOMS IN ON the drive-in screen and the words that America has waited twenty-five years to see in 70mm Dolby(TM) drop- your-popcorn reality:

dialogues.speaker: THE FLINTSTONES
dialogues.text: And as the MAIN CREDITS ROLL, we --

dialogues.speaker: AN EERIE CARBONIFEROUS FOREST
dialogues.text: Dew drips from strange multi-leafed plants. Giant DRAGONFLIES BUZZ AND HUM to and fro. Bubbles rise from a still pond, and weird lungfish move onto the land. (The third one out carries a little suitcase.) CAMERA PANS PAST the lungfish TO a muddy shore. With a DRAMATIC MUSICAL STING, we DISCOVER a set of strange, hideous clawprints. The CAMERA FOLLOWS these, then WIDENS to reveal the make of these footprints: A seven- foot tall and fearful beast we will call the Xenosaurus. It looks around menacingly. (Oddly, it's carrying a canvas sack, but we don't stress this.) Suddenly a garbage truck appears out of nowhere and runs over the Xenosaurus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dazed, the Xenosaurus gets up. As it does, we realize that we aren't deep in some primeval forest, but on the shoulder of a gravel highway. A stone road sign reads

dialogues.speaker: BEDROCK 1/2 MILE. ROCK VEGAS, BABYLON
dialogues.text: EXITS. Now, the CAMERA CRANES UP ABOVE the sign and we see -- Bedrock! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Nestled incongruously in a savage landscape, the charming protosuburbia gleams in the dawn's early Spielberg light. The Xenosaurus grabs its sack and some silverware spills out. Then it runs off into the bushes and out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: WITH THAT GARBAGE TRUCK 8
dialogues.text: It reaches the crest of a hill where there's a "WELCOME TO BEDROCK" billboard which bears greetings from the Rotary Club, the Chamber of Commerce, and (of course) The Loyal Order of Water Buffaloes. The garbage truck guys drop their feet down through the floorboard and trot over the rise, coast down to the street below. The driver yanks a wooden brake and the truck stops, and the rear guys hop off. One of them waves to --

dialogues.speaker: A MILKMAN 9
dialogues.text: who returns the wave, then takes a four-pack of stone bottles out of his milk truck, heads towards a doorway. As the milkman drops off the milk, he passes a big TORTOISE with trash cans on its back. The Tortoise nods familiarly to the milkman, then it waddles down the curb, CAMERA FOLLOWING. The garbage men take the cans off the Tortoise's back, dump them into the truck.

dialogues.speaker: REAR OF TRUCK 10
dialogues.text: -- revealing that the back of the truck is actually a giant-jawed CREATURE strapped onto the chassis. The garbage men dump the cans into its maw... it happily swallows the works, licks its lips, BELCHES.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE 11
dialogues.text: The garbagemen slam the cans back on the Tortoise, who winces as they drive off.

dialogues.speaker: TORTOISE
dialogues.text: (under his breath) You can forget about a tip for Christmas... It waddles back up the lawn... passing by a wooden "lawn timer" box which now pops open. Inside the box is a "ROOSTERSAURUS" which CROWS and flaps its wings. The motion of the wings knocks loose two round stones which roll down two long troughs a la Rube Goldberg...  12 13 14 15 16

dialogues.speaker: FOLLOWING THE ROUND STONES 12
dialogues.text: They reach the ends of their respective paths, dislodging a stick... that releases a coiled rope which in turn spins a turntable which holds a little wooly mammoth. As it begins to spin around, it squirts water out of its snout. Elsewhere on the lawn, other spinning MAMMOTHS repeat this performance. After a moment, they gradually slow their revolutions. The one closest to the house scrunches its trunk with a GROAN.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE MAMMOTH
dialogues.text: (sotto) Oh, my aching sinuses...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDEN FROM the windowsill, where a little sea shell hearing aid trumpet AMPLIFIES another ROOSTERSAURUS "COCK-A-DOODLE-DOO" into the ear of a "CLOCK RADIO WOODPECKER." The Woodpecker yawns, gets out of bed, puts a timecard in a little clock. Then it turns and begins pecking on a BELL, which RINGS PIERCINGLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two shapes are visible under the bedclothes: One is a great SNORING bulge, the other is a svelte and lithe shape. As the BELL continues RINGING, the larger bulge GRUNTS, MOANS, pulls a pillow over its head, and then finally gropes under the bed for a slipper. The slipper is thrown without aiming --

dialogues.speaker: THE WOODPECKER 15
dialogues.text: ducks just in time. It wipes its forehead nervously.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO WOODPECKER
dialogues.text: (sotto) I hate this job... There's not even a health plan... He staggers back up to his perch, and then notices for the first time that the dial on the side is pointed not to "ALARM" but to "ALARM & RADIO." The WOODPECKER SIGHS, looks over at the bed where SNORING is still emanating. Then the bird swings a little telescope around to point out the window.

dialogues.speaker: WOODPECKER'S TELESCOPE
dialogues.text: as the 'SCOPE PANS and FOCUSES, finally SETTLING ON a distant stone building marked RADIO STATION B-ROK. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Perched on top of the wooden radio tower are a monkey and an octopus. The monkey holds up cue cards which the octopus reads, and then waves nautical semaphore flags.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE 17
dialogues.text: Our WOODPECKER squints, CLEARS his THROAT.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO WOODPECKER
dialogues.text: (deeper "on-air" voice) Good morning, Bedrock. This is station B-R-O-K with the morning weather and news...

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BED 18
dialogues.text: The big bulge GRUNTS and MUTTERS a bit, then one hand gropes around, finds the curvaceous form under the neighboring covers... feels it tentatively... then the fingers "walk" upwards...

dialogues.speaker: RADIO WOODPECKER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It will be fair and mild through the weekend, continuing for the next eight hundred years, followed by cooling breezes and a protracted ice age... Those walking fingers have reached the top edge of the covers... now they pull them down revealing the owner's face... the face of Fred, his eyes at half-mast, his face covered in fashionable "Bedrock Vice" stubble.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (with genuine charm) Wil-ma. Wil-ma? How about a great big good morning kiss for your Freddy-weddy? And he pulls the covers down to reveal -- DINO, who is immediately "YI-YI-YI-YI-ING," hopping all over the bed and showering Fred with sloppy kisses.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Dino! Dino, cut it out -- !

dialogues.speaker: RADIO WOODPECKER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: In the news, Bedrock civic and business leaders met yesterday to discuss the growing kibble crisis. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RADIO WOODPECKER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ecological activist Ralph Naderock warned that if new supplies of kibble are not found, our animal- powered civilization itself may be threatened. By now Dino's affection attack has knocked both master and pet to the floor in a jumble of bedclothes, asses and elbows. Dino begins to roll Fred across the room like a seal playing with a ball.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Dino, that's enough -- here, look Daddy has a nice dino bone for you, just please stop it -- Fred has now backed up to a dresser, where he grabs a brightly-colored box labeled "PURINROCK DINO TREATS." Fred holds it up -- Dino gets up on two legs, eager for the treat -- Fred shakes the box... alas, nothing comes out. DINO "YI-YI'S" again, propelling Fred into the next room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five-year-old PEBBLES GIGGLES at the table as Fred and Dino tumble into the room like Frank Buck and a lion. Wilma turns at the noise. One look at her and we under- stand Fred's romantic turn.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO WOODPECKER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: In other news, Bedrock police report that the Xenosaurus has struck again! Yes, the fiercesome intruder was sighted in the Bedrock Hills for the third time this month. Outlying shops and residencies report extensive looting and property destruction...

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: Fred, stop playing with Dino and sit down. Your breakfast's getting cold. Saying this, Wilma puts a huge egg at Fred's place. Meanwhile, Fred manages to get to his feet, holds out one arm to keep Dino at bay. Fred does a big "take," looking out the window -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (throwing open the door) Oooh, Dino, look -- there's a nice big dino bone laying out on the front lawn -- ! Pause. Dino gives him a big look as if to say, "Oh, yeah?"

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (trying again) -- Gosh, look at that adorable little female dino -- "YI-YI-YI-YI," DINO is out the door like a rocket. Fred cackles, slams it shut, then sits down at the table.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: -- That animal's gonna kill me with kindness. Do you know we're out of dino treats?

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: So is everybody else in Bedrock. That kibble crisis is getting worse every day. She puts two giant slices of bread into a toaster. Two claw-like devices hold the toast, pulling it out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: I'm afraid Dino's going to have to manage on leftovers from Pebbles and me.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (sitting down) And what's wrong with my leftovers?

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: I'll let you know when I see some.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO WOODPECKER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (finishing up) . Scientists from B.C. University report that the footprints of the Xenosaurus match no known animal. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PEBBLES
dialogues.text: Mommy, is the bad Ze-ze-zenosaurus gonna get me and eat me up?

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: Of course not, baby.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: That's right, sweetheart. The only thing that's gonna eat you up is -- me! And he grabs her and bites her and tickles her.

dialogues.speaker: PEBBLES
dialogues.text: (giggling, calming) I'm still a little scared...

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Pebbles, don't worry. These stories are very exaggerated. Like, you know, the boogyman? There's no such thing as a huge, inhuman reptile that attacks without warning -- WHAM! Dino reappears, bounding through the window and knocking Fred onto the floor. Once again Dino is happily licking and loving and cuddling his callously unresponsive owner. Fred struggles to avoid the slurping tongue, pulls himself up to the window sill, looks out.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: -- Oh, look, everybody, the mailman is here -- "YI-YI-YI-YI!" DINO buys it again, runs to the door lets himself out. This time Fred puts a chair against the door. Meanwhile, Wilma turns at the sound of the TOASTER POPPING UP. We see that the "claws" we saw earlier were the actual claws of a LOBSTER in a little fireproof suit who is tucked inside the toaster. As Wilma takes the toast, the Lobster blows on his claws, wincing, then looks TOWARDS the CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: LOBSTER
dialogues.text: Well, it beats working ina seafood restaurant... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (taking the toast) Thanks, Wilma... Fred slaps jelly on the toast, takes a big bite, and then something outside the window catches his eye.

dialogues.speaker: STREET 20
dialogues.text: A paperboy on a wood-and-stone bicycle is coming rapidly towards the house. In the bike's basket is a stack of dried, rock-hard clay tablets.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE 21
dialogues.text: Fred leans out the window, waving his hands.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Arnold! Arnold! Don't aim at the house -- please, not at the house -- WHAM! Fred ducks back just as the stone newspaper slams into the window frame, SMASHING a FLOWERPOT, taking out a chunk of wall, and continuing diagonally through the kitchen and out another window. Fred follows this action in time to see --

dialogues.speaker: HIS DRIVEWAY
dialogues.text: The rock paper drops like a foul shot, rips through the canvas roof of Fred's car, and then bangs a huge dent in the hood.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE 23
dialogues.text: Fred sighs, turns back to his breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: Lucky it wasn't the Sunday paper.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (slight smile) Yeah. What else can go wrong? He slices through the big egg with his knife -- releasing a baby PTERODACTYL which SQUAWKS and flaps, knocking Fred over as it takes off through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred -- now dressed for work -- is forlornly trying to fix his car. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: In the neighboring driveway, Wilma and Betty pile the kids into Betty's car.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (wiping their mouths) Come on, kids. Time for nursery school.

dialogues.speaker: PEBBLES
dialogues.text: "Bye-bye, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: "Bye, little sweetheart. (as Wilma clears her throat) "Bye, big sweetheart. Fred kisses them both and they drive off. Fred sighs, tries to stretch the canvas roof edges close enough to stitch. Nearby, Dino struggles to drag the stone news- paper inside the house. The twin headlines are, of course, KIBBLE CRISIS GROWS and MYSTERIOUS XENOSAURUS STRIKES AGAIN. Suddenly a pink flamingo appears over the hedge. As its mouth opens and closes, it appears to be talking, but the voice is that of --

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Nice morning, huh, Fred?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: What's nice about it?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Heh, hey. That Arnold's got a real arm on him, don't he? Now we see that Barney is holding the flamingo's stiff legs which he scissors, making the bird's beak trim the hedge.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: This is the third ragtop this year say, shouldn't you be at work?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Ah, well, that appliance store and me, we kinda had a little adjustment --

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: You got fired, didn't ya? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Fred, don't start on me again. I donno, I'm just not a nine to five guy. I got dreams, Fred. Ideas --

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know, I know, those crazy inventions of yours. Be honest with me, Barn... tell me one thing you invented that really caught on.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I invented fire.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (pause) You invented fire?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I told you that, Fred. But the coal conglomerate ripped me off. The case is still in court, but meanwhile I got lotsa other ideas --

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Yeah, but did any one of them ever put bread on the table? How long are you and Betty gonna live on those penny-ante royalties you get? Fred pulls his car hood off of its wooden hinges, examines it with dismay.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: If you ask me, pal, you're just blowing smoke up your own volcano...

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Maybe, Fred. But first... He uses the flamingo's jaws to snatch the car hood from Fred's surprised grasp.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Let me try some of that smoke on your car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can still see Fred's car in the neighboring driveway. (We can also see Dino, who drags the newspaper on a bit more, then collapses from exhaustion). Barney's garage is cluttered with all kinds of odds and ends, plus various inventions and scale models in different stages of completion. (Interestingly, a number of these anticipate Leonardo da Vinci's work). Many of the models are made of a strange celadon green material. Fred watches, skeptical, as Barney presses the car hood into some soft clay between two big blocks of stone.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (as he works) -- See, the first step, we make a mold of the old car hood, smooth out the dent in the clay -- He tosses the original car hood aside with a crash. Then, moving rapidly, he starts heaving a variety of ingredients into the reverse imprint of the car hood.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: -- Add some lava granules... some woca leaves... juice from two coo-coo berries...

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (impressed) Two coo-coo berries? You made of money, Barney?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Anything for a pal, Fred -- a lump of coal... bamboo sawdust... eucalyptus sap... a touch of the La Brea tarbrush -- and -- voila. Barney dips a finger in this mess, "tastes" it; satisfied, he yanks on a hanging rope and a giant rock weight slams down on the whole mess, making Fred jump out of his skin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred is caked with dust. He coughs and spits.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Barney, why don't you try inventing a brain for yourself! Look at what you did to -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He stops as Barney cranks up the weight on a ratchet, proudly lifts out a perfect (though greenish) duplicate of the car hood. As Fred examines it, impressed despite himself, we...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY'S CAR
dialogues.text: The two kids are in the back seat. Somehow both of the kids' faces are messy again. Working together with beautiful precision, they are carefully dismantling the rear armrests and door handles.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (in mid-speech, driving) . Oh, it's not that I'm complaining, Wilma. I mean, Barney's sweet, but... well, he's just not cut out to punch a clock. And he's such a dreamer you think he ever once picked up a hammer and chisel and tried to balance a checkbook? They pull up in front of a pleasant-looking simple little nursery school. MRS. GRANITE, a pleasant-looking 65, sees them from the schoolyard, waves while Wilma and Betty un- load the kids.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: No, Barney just keeps looking for that coo-coo berry pie in the sky, and I don't want to pop his balloon by talking about the price of mastodon ribs. She wipes off Bam-Bam's mouth with a handkerchief. Wilma does the same with Pebbles and then they kiss the kids, who immediately run into the schoolyard.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRANITE
dialogues.text: (approaching) Mrs. Rubble, Mrs. Flintstone, I wanted to thank you personally.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: You're welcome, Mrs. Granite. But we wipe their mouths every day.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRANITE
dialogues.text: No, no, I mean for all your wonderful support the past few years. It's parents like you that make me think twice about retiring. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: From the schoolyard comes the sudden sound of KIDS QUAR- RELING and then a THUD and some CRYING.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRANITE
dialogues.text: On the other hand... Wilma and Betty laugh.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: We're really going to miss you, too, Mrs. Granite.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GRANITE
dialogues.text: Have you found another school for the children?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: We're still shopping around.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: Fortunately, we're both -- Wilma and Betty straighten... salute.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: (they've done this routine before) -- Professional shoppers! As the three women laugh, we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred and Barney drive along. (Behind them, the same houses and palms seem to be going by... duplex, palm... split level, two palms... duplex, palm). Barney grins, gestures towards the front of the car.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Not bad, eh? After it cures for an hour or so, it's solid as a rock.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Okay, you fixed a dented hood. But you call that a living? Face it, pal, this is the Stone Age, and it's a dino eat dino world. You want my advice?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Did I ever? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: You stick with me today, cruise on down to the quarry and fill out a job application. I'm a big man there, Barney --

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: You're a big man anywhere, Fred --

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: I'm serious, pal. Me and Mr. Slate are just like this -- He takes his hand off the wheel to hold up two fingers... ends up swerving instead.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: -- just like that. I know, I know -- you're not a clock-punching guy -- but face it, Barney -- it's time to grow up and put your nose to the grindstone, batten down the hatches and join the ratasaurus race with the rest of us. (meaningfully) It's time to retire those dreams. Barney looks glum, doesn't say anything. Suddenly Fred pulls over, stops the car.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Barney. Look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're at the crest of a high wide hill.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Hey. Lava Lane.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Remember the old days, Barn? We used to race our go-carts here to impress the girls.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (wistful) Yeah, those were the days... we usta dream about coming back here some day with a real car and goin' for the goldrock...! A look from one to another, and then down the hill... Fred gets a malicious grin on his face. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Fred... I thought you said it was time to retire those old dreams.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Hey. Since when do I have to be consistent? The two pals laugh, and then with a whoop they begin pedalling like mad. They go over the top, gravity takes over and they are flying past that billboard with all the Rotary Club welcomes on it. But now we see a different sort of welcome, as a POLICE CAR ZOOMS out from behind it

dialogues.speaker: POLICE CAR
dialogues.text: Inside are SERGEANT FELDSPAR and his rookie partner OFFICER GRAVEL. Cackling with anticipation, Feldspar opens a box marked radar detector. Out pops a little bird in a police helmet. It has a stopwatch (actually, stop-sundial) around its neck. Feldspar points -- the bird salutes -- takes off!

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (spotting the cops) Oh-oh! Fred, slow down -- ! Suddenly both Fred and Barney see the RADAR BIRD flying alongside them. It checks its stopwatch, writes a note to itself. Fred is so preoccupied he doesn't notice as --

dialogues.speaker: THE POLICE CAR 32
dialogues.text: cuts in front of Fred. Fred SLAMS on the "BRAKES," sits helplessly as Feldspar gets out, walks over, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: FELDSPAR
dialogues.text: Well, Flintstone, looks like today's the day.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Sergeant Feldspar, I... I wasn't speeding... honest... Fred reaches down to the floorboard as he speaks...

dialogues.speaker: FLOORBOARD 33
dialogues.text: There's a box there marked RADAR BUSTER. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FELDSPAR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Forget it, Flintstone. This time I got you dead to rights -- Fred opens the box. A scary-looking winged reptile sticks out its head, smacks its hungry lips.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE 34
dialogues.text: Confident, Feldspar jerks a thumb at the Radar Bird, turns to his rookie partner.

dialogues.speaker: FELDSPAR
dialogues.text: Gravel. Get me the radar reading and I'll show you how we deal with scofflaws. Gravel nods, steps towards the bird. The bird checks its stopwatch... and then it notices the flying lizard which is hovering nearby, licking its lips.

dialogues.speaker: RADAR BIRD
dialogues.text: Whoa! Wings, do your stuff -- ! The Radar Bird flies away at a hundred miles an hour leaving a cloud of dust and the stopwatch behind. Feldspar catches the watch, startled.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Well, Sergeant, if you don't have a radar reading, I guess we'll -- (quickly) -- justbeonourway -- ! A new cloud of dust appears as Fred ROARS away.

dialogues.speaker: FELDSPAR
dialogues.text: Flintstone! Flintstone, come back here -- !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty and Wilma have just pulled up. We notice that next to their legal spot, a big limousine is parked in a "no parking" zone. But our law-abiding Betty in the next space now drops a stone coin in a parking meter.

dialogues.speaker: THE METER 36
dialogues.text: Inside the window we see a LITTLE BIRD. It "bites" the coin to check it, then turns over an egg timer. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BIRD
dialogues.text: (with a sigh) Four years in accounting school for this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's absolutely mobbed. Customers push past each other with armloads of food. Gigantic cuts of meat hang from above or are on display behind the counter. MORRIS THE BUTCHER looks up from the chaos and manages a weak smile for the girls.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Morris, what on earth is going on? You giving away Bronto filets?

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Ah, my two loveliest customers. It's this darn kibble crisis, Mrs. R... people are buying everything I got to feed their dinos...

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SLATE
dialogues.text: Young man, if you're through flirting, I'd like some service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVEALING MRS. SLATE, who stands there, impatient and overdressed.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Of course, Mrs. Slate. Just take a number. Wilma senses the tension, quickly steps forward to break it with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: Ah, hello, Mrs. Slate. Morris reacts with relief. Mrs. Slate reacts with a blank look.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: (prompting) We met at the quarry picnic?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SLATE
dialogues.text: Oh, of course. Mrs. Flintstein. She turns her back to Wilma, forces her way towards the counter again. Wilma burns. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Ladies, the meat's not getting any fresher. Mrs. R, what'll it be?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Oh, I'd like some ground mammoth patties and uh... some dodo drumsticks.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Gino? We got any dodo bird? GINO turns, looks at his end of the counter. Gino nods,

dialogues.speaker: GINO
dialogues.text: There's one left -- and it's the last one!

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Good. (handing him the note) Give it to Mrs. Rubble along with this. smiling. He picks up a crate, begins to load it with giant fryer parts and several manhole-sized meat patties.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: (turning to Betty) How about you, Mrs. F?

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: I just need a few things for Fred.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: "Fred...'? (calling into the back) David! Herman! Get Rob and BoBo and tell â€˜em to bring the big dolly!

dialogues.speaker: VOICE FROM BACK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Flintstone again, huh?

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: You got it. Now then... Mrs. Slate? (pointing at the limo outside the shop) You're in a no parking zone there. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SLATE
dialogues.text: Well, if I get some service, I'll be out of it, won't I? Mrs. Slate steps to the counter. Meanwhile, the staff begin using a refrigerator dolly to bring out giant ribs, steaks and sausages which they pile up in front of Wilma.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SLATE
dialogues.text: I want a nice fresh, juicy chickensaurus, Morris. And not one you've had laying around on the shelf. I mean fresh.

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Mrs. Slate, we're kind of busy now --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SLATE
dialogues.text: I don't care if you're busy. What I care about is my adorable little grand nephew. He's staying with me for the summer and I intend to make his favorite dish... Southern fried chickensaurus! Now I want a fresh chickensaurus and I want it now!

dialogues.speaker: MORRIS
dialogues.text: Boys, you heard her... she said fresh.

dialogues.speaker: THE STAFF 39
dialogues.text: with a sigh, they buckle on elbow and knee protectors, go to a side door, open it. Inside is another barred door. They open it, go inside. Immediately we hear loud SQUAWKING and CACKLING... THUDS, BUMPS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the barred door slams open and a giant chicken- saurus comes bounding out, with Morris's staff hanging all over it like rodeo cowboys. They try and restrain it with ropes but it's enraged and flops around the store.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SLATE
dialogues.text: (oblivious of the trouble) Morris, while you're at it, I'd like it plucked -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Suddenly the chickensaurus snaps the ropes, flaps its wings and leaps through the front window --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The huge bird lands with a crunch atop Mrs. Slate's car, which is practically squashed flat. Then it disappears around the corner. (We hear CAR HORNS and SKIDDING TIRES as it goes.)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SLATE
dialogues.text: My car -- ! Wilma and Betty try and hide their laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clouds of dust rise from behind the fence. We see the heads of the heavy equipment dinos rising and falling. A two-story office building is at one end of the site with a big "Slate Construction Inc." sign on the roof. CAMERA ADJUSTS as Fred's car turns into the lot, Barney seated beside Fred. The new green hood gleams in the morning light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred digs his feet into the ground, slams to a halt. He gets out, surveys the activity. Immediately, the various workers shout AD LIB greetings. Fred acknowledges these, beaming in the respect he gets here. He lovingly dusts off his construction helmet, puts it on knocks an offending speck from his parking sign (F. Flintstone - Shop Steward). He leads Barney towards the quarry area.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Barney, you won't regret this -- hiya, Al -- fixing dents in cars is one thing, a career's another. Here, you're getting in on the ground floor of the first footstep of a new leaf -- hi, Wally, how's the old backhand? And with a guy like me ta show you the ropes, you can skip all the red tape, all the malarky, all the dino doo --  22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred stands near the weight station booth, where a plump GIRL in a beehive hairdo sits inside a trailer.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (New York accent) Hi, Mr. Flintstone.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Hiya, Shirley. This is my very special neighbor and pal Barney Rubble. He needs an application form, okay?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Anything for you, Mr. Flintstone. She slams down two clay tablets and a stylus.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Here you go. (smiling) Thanks again for the football tickets. My boyfriend and I both liked them.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: My pleasure, Shirl. Anytime.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Okay. But do you think next time we could go to the same game?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (confidently) No problem. Fred smiles at her, hands the forms to Barney. Fres steps towards the quarry, admires the activity, hands on hips, master of all he surveys. He waves to more friends.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Well, Barn, what did I tell you? When you're in with Flintstone, you're in like Flint.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Gee, Fred. I knew you were a big shot. I just didn't know how big. Fred beams at that, and then follows Barney's gaze to the read-out on the truck scale. Fred is standing on it and it's pushing 250. With a scowl, Fred grabs Barney's sleeve and they go into the quarry. As they move, the CAMERA PANS and CRANES UP TOWARDS the window of the Slate Construction Office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room here is dominated by a tabletop architectural model of a large scale construction project. There's acres of little development houses, then some tall office buildings, a mall, you name it: There's even little foot- powered model cars in the model parking spaces. Near this we see MR. SLATE, a giant in the Bedrock con- struction business (but not in height). Slate drinks coffee from a "Boss" mug, listens with growing impatience to JERRY LAVA. Several of Slate's lackeys listen, their heads nodding up or down in sympathy with Slate's mer- curial moods.

dialogues.speaker: LAVA
dialogues.text: Uncle, if you'll look at this unit cost projection... it intersects here with --

dialogues.speaker: SLATE
dialogues.text: -- how'd you like my fist to intersect with your nose? I've told you a hundred times, don't call me uncle in the office! Now, I didn't arrange your scholarship to Harvrock University so you could waste my time! So stop beating around the bushasaurus and get to the bottom slime!

dialogues.speaker: LAVA
dialogues.text: You'll be bankrupt in six months. Slate does a Danny Thomas spit take all over the model.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred and Barney cross the busy lot, sidestepping workers and animals. Fred does a lot of backslapping, waving. Barney's filling out the forms on the move. Behind them, we see the wide access ramp which spirals around the quarry's sides.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (to himself) Social Security number... dependents... â€˜how learned of job' newspaper ad, carrier pigeon... (writing) Personal reference... Hearing a loud SMASH, Fred looks up and sees --

dialogues.speaker: A WRECKING BALL OPERATOR 48
dialogues.text: A burly and rough looking guy named PILTDOWN, he grins in side his dino-topping cupola, winds his winch handles and then propels his wrecking ball towards the...  49 50 51 24.

dialogues.speaker: QUARRY WALL
dialogues.text: -- where the huge stone BALL SMASHES into some walnuts balanced on a boulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Piltdown's compact buddy PYRITE cackles, sweeps up the walnuts. Munching them, he balances a new one in place. (It should be noted here that the relationship and physi- cal appearances of Piltdown and Pyrite mirrors that of our heroes... they're sort of an anti-Fred and Barney.)

dialogues.speaker: PYRITE
dialogues.text: Way ta go, Pilty baby. Five bucks says you can't hit one on the fly.

dialogues.speaker: PILTDOWN
dialogues.text: (calling up) Yer on, Pyrite -- Pyrite tosses a walnut, which bounces on the ledge. The wrecking BALL SMASHES into the stone wall.

dialogues.speaker: BELOW 51
dialogues.text: Workers near Fred duck as dust and debris fall down. People grab for their construction helmets.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Not again... Fred hustles up a ladder to a ramp which leads him up to the level of Piltdown's cab. Barney hurries to follow.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: All right, Piltdown, that's enough! You're endangering your fellow workers!

dialogues.speaker: PILTDOWN
dialogues.text: Yeah? Sez who?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Says me, Fred Flintstone -- shop steward of Amalgamated Neolithic Workers 101.

dialogues.speaker: PILTDOWN
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well, A.N.W. one-oh-one gives us workers a snack break. So... (a nasty grin) I'm breakin' some snacks. He swings the wrecking ball again.  52 53 54 55 56 25.

dialogues.speaker: UP ABOVE 52
dialogues.text: This time he's overdone it: The wrecking ball flies past the walnuts -- Pyrite ducks for cover -- and then the wrecking ball whips over and around the handrail which runs along here, twisting as tightly as Indiana Jones' whip. The handrail wobbles dangerously in its foundation --

dialogues.speaker: PILTDOWN'S DINO 53
dialogues.text: SNORTS, backs up -- the crane SUPPORTS on its back begin to CREAK and GROAN with the strain --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Workers scatter, fearful of the imminent collapse. Fred runs to grab the dino's reins.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa, big fella -- He calms the beast by giving it a carrot. As it munches, Fred quickly ties the reins to a post.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (calling up to the cab) You're on report, Piltdown! If it's up to me you'll be pushing a wheelbarrow!

dialogues.speaker: PILTDOWN
dialogues.text: (leaping down) You've been asking for this, Flintstone... I'm gonna kick your fat butt --

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Fat butt? Hold me back, Barney -- (sotto, very sincere) -- Barney, hold me back -- Quickly the men form a circle around Piltdown and Fred. Barney looks up and sees --

dialogues.speaker: THE DINO'S BACK 55
dialogues.text: It is shuddering and threatening to come crashing down.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Hey, maybe you guys oughta fix that first.

dialogues.speaker: PILTDOWN
dialogues.text: Why should we? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: It looks dangerous. Besides, you can kick Fred's fat butt anytime.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Yeah. That's right. (realizing, a glare at Barney) I mean -- this ain't over, Piltdown. (turning, shouting) Come on, guys. Let's clean up the mess. With much grumbling, ropes and grappling hooks are gathered and the crew hops to it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slate stands in a blubbering fury as Lava mops coffee up from the model and Slate's face.

dialogues.speaker: SLATE
dialogues.text: Bankrupt? Are you crazy? Lava holds up a clay tablet covered with figures.

dialogues.speaker: LAVA
dialogues.text: It's all here in hack and slice. When you committed to this housing development the price of dino kibble was a few clams per ton. Since then, it's gone up a hundredfold. (indicating the model) You can't build a project like this without the heavy equipment dinos, and we can't afford to feed those dinos. Slate glowers, paces around the model.

dialogues.speaker: SLATE
dialogues.text: I'm two months behind schedule, my option's running out on the land and Donald Trumprock is just waiting to jump in and steal the whole deal .. meanwhile that damn union's on my back, hell, they'll probably want an eighty hour week or something... (frustrated) There's got to be an answer... A LOUD COMMOTION outside the window attracts everyone's attention. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SLATE
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: LAVA
dialogues.text: (worried) Sounds like a worker's comp claim if I ever heard one... All rush to the window. They look out and see --

dialogues.speaker: THE QUARRY
dialogues.text: Supervised by Fred, all the workers are straining on the ropes to haul the rear legs of the crane back into their sockets on the back of the big dino. Only the last critical rope is still dangling.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Barney! Grab that line! Hurry! Barney scrambles up Fred's back, shoving a foot in Fred's face, but finally snatching the rope. He pulls on it... Fred throws his own weight into the effort...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THUDS into place on the dino's back -- the workers cheer

dialogues.speaker: THE WRECKING BALL 60
dialogues.text: alas, with its cable now twisted shorter, it's become an immovable object, and as the shortened CABLE SNAPS, the wrecking ball begins to roll down the quarry wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men and ANIMALS YELP and dive out of the way as the BALL rolls downwards, SMASHING everything in its path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The executives watch concerned as --

dialogues.speaker: THE WRECKING BALL 63
dialogues.text: tumbles down, down, knocking scaffolding and ladders aside, reaches the end of a ramp, and drops through the air right onto --

dialogues.speaker: THE HOOD OF FRED'S CAR 64
dialogues.text: -- where, astonishingly, the HOOD sinks in resiliently like a trampoline and then with a loud "SPROING" the wrecking ball flies straight back up into the air followed a beat behind by the unhinged hood itself. Both hurtle TOWARDS the CAMERA --  65 66 67 68 69 70 28.

dialogues.speaker: SLATE AND EXECUTIVES 65
dialogues.text: react fearfully as they realize all this is coming straight for them. With a howl, they all dive aside --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wrecking BALL flies through the window, SLAMS onto Slate's desk, crushing everything in its path and then sails on SMASHING right into --

dialogues.speaker: THE MODEL DEVELOPMENT 67
dialogues.text: -- where all of the lined up HIGH RISES SMASH ASIDE with a sound like falling pins.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE QUARRY 68
dialogues.text: The workers pick themselves up and now their eyes follow the path taken by the long-gone wrecking ball.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Oh boy. Goodbye pension fund -- They rush for the office building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dust is still settling. The staff rises from the mess, coughing. Lava rummages in the debris, finds a stiff body.

dialogues.speaker: LAVA
dialogues.text: Uncle, Uncle, speak to me -- But it's only a statue of a golfer from one of Slate's trophies.

dialogues.speaker: SLATE
dialogues.text: (sitting up) I'm over here, you moron -- and don't call me 'Uncle'! Slate's eyes fall on Fred's car hood, swinging from a bookshelf. He reaches for it -- pulls it -- it stays put, and only releases a new deluge of rubble and plaster which reburies him. At the same time, the door slams open and Fred, Barney and the other workers tumble inside

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE 70
dialogues.text: As they take in the destruction. Barney notices the wrecking ball amidst the model buildings. As we watch, the last remaining little HIGH RISE FALLS. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Hey, nice going, Fred. You even got the spare --

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Barney, shut up -- (turning) Mr. Slate -- Mr. Slate -- are you all right? Slate staggers to his feet, seething with fury. He finally yanks the car hood free. It bounces and VIBRATES in his hands like a hand saw.

dialogues.speaker: SLATE
dialogues.text: (eying the men) For five years Slate Construction has had the finest safety record in Bedrock. (pacing, angry) Our workers are trained in first aid, our equipment is first rate and our dinos are worm free. And then something like this happens I want to know how! A cacophony of voices starts to answer.

dialogues.speaker: SLATE
dialogues.text: Shut up! (in the sudden silence) I want one person to answer me: (waving the car hood) Who's responsible for this?

dialogues.speaker: PILTDOWN 71
dialogues.text: nudges the wrecking ball off the edge of the table. It falls on Fred's foot. Fred starts to scream and Piltdown shoves a pencil holder into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: PILTDOWN
dialogues.text: (quickly) It was Flintstone, Mr. Slate!

dialogues.speaker: PYRITE
dialogues.text: That's right, Mr. Slate, it was Flintstone!

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: That's a lie, Mr. Slate!

dialogues.speaker: SLATE
dialogues.text: Who are you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (pointing to his forms) B. Rubble. White male personal reference --

dialogues.speaker: SLATE
dialogues.text: (pushing Barney aside) Flintstone, I have just one thing to say to you -- Fred cringes. Piltdown and Pyrite smirk.

dialogues.speaker: SLATE
dialogues.text: (pumping his hand) Congratulations!

dialogues.speaker: FRED PILTDOWN
dialogues.text: Huh? What?

dialogues.speaker: SLATE
dialogues.text: This stuff you had on your car is the most incredible building material I've seen in thirty years in the construction business! (testing it) It's strong -- (twirling it) -- Light -- (bending it) -- Resilient -- It rebounds, "SPROINGING" him on the chin. He recovers, shakes it off.

dialogues.speaker: SLATE
dialogues.text: Where on earth did you get it?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Oh, it's ah, just something I whipped up in the old garage workshop -- (quickly) -- with a little help from my buddy Barney, right, Barn?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Well, actually, Fred, it was the other way ar-- Fred hisses between his teeth, repeats the "Slate and me are just like this" gesture he made earlier, points at Slate. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (reluctant ) Sure, Fred, right, right. Slate nods, distracted, his eyes and hands running over the smooth lines of the car hood.

dialogues.speaker: SLATE
dialogues.text: The rest of you men go back to work. I want to talk to Flintstone and the personal reference alone. Come on, move, move... They go out, Piltdown looking furious.

dialogues.speaker: SLATE
dialogues.text: (a man in love) Light as a Pterodactyl feather... why, a child could handle this... Lava, we could cut construction costs in half... in quarters... in uh... whatchacallit --

dialogues.speaker: LAVA
dialogues.text: (patiently) Eighths --

dialogues.speaker: SLATE
dialogues.text: Eighths, right. Flintstone, what do you call this stuff?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Well, Mr. Slate, I call it -- (hesitating, sotto) -- Barney, what do I call it?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (sotto) Fibrerock, Fred...

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: -- I call it Fibrerock Fred -- ! (realizing) I mean, ah, 'Fibrerock'!

dialogues.speaker: SLATE
dialogues.text: (rolling it over his tongue) "Fibrerock'? 'Fibrerock'? (playing with it) '"Fib-bre-rock' -- Slate's staff make disparaging noises. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SLATE
dialogues.text: I love it!

dialogues.speaker: SLATE'S STAFF
dialogues.text: (instantly reversing themselves) Love it... great... has a nice ring... says it all, you know? (Etc...) Slate takes the piece of material, leans it on the table so it catches the light. Despite himself, Lava comes over, examines the car hood... can't help but marvel at it as well. Meanwhile, Slate puts his arms around Fred and Barney.

dialogues.speaker: SLATE
dialogues.text: (to Lava) You see this, Lava? All those courses of yours at Harvrock University, and who saves my bacon? Two simple-minded run-of-the-mill nobodies.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Gee, thanks, Mr. Slate. Lava glowers. Slate pulls Fred and Barney close with genuine excitement.

dialogues.speaker: SLATE
dialogues.text: Boys, this is a small step for Slate Construction... a giant step for all mankind. He points to the translucent material. CAMERA TIGHTENS ON it. We see Fred, Barney and Slate's reflections in it.

dialogues.speaker: SLATE
dialogues.text: (dramatically) The Stone Age is over! Let the Fibre Age begin! As HEROIC MUSIC STINGS IN, we...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY'S CAR
dialogues.text: Mrs. Slate is in back, crammed in with groceries. Betty pulls up in front of a building that looks like a Palm Springs spa. This is "L'ECOLE DES ENFANTS PREHISTORIQUE

dialogues.speaker: HAUTE SUPERIOR."
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Here we are, Mrs. Slate. Sorry you had to ride in the back.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SLATE
dialogues.text: (getting out) Not at all. I'm used to being driven around. And she's sashaying up the path. Betty and Wilma burn, then follow her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As elegant as we can get MMMCXV years before Louis XIV. As the three women come in, we see CHILDREN with alliga- tors on their deerskin shirts singing:

dialogues.speaker: CHILDREN
dialogues.text: "La hachette de ma tante est sur le roche de mon oncle -- '

dialogues.speaker: HEADMISTRESS
dialogues.text: (coming over, gushing) Madame Mrs. Slate, bonjour! Welcome to L'ecole des Enfants Prehistorique Haute Superior!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SLATE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Marie. (showing a rock receipt) I ordered the hors d'oeuvres for the junior talent show. They were out of Ceolanth caviar so I got Mastodon brie instead. Oh, ah, these are my, uh, friends, Wilma Flintstein --

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: Flintstone --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SLATE
dialogues.text: -- oh, it used to be Flintstein -- ? And this is ah, Becky... Betty! The Headmistress reaches over, takes their hands gracefully.

dialogues.speaker: HEADMISTRESS
dialogues.text: Enchante.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: I'm sure. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Likewise.

dialogues.speaker: HEADMISTRESS
dialogues.text: (waving a hand) Well, Madame Slate, as you can see, we remain ze creme de la creme in the croissant of life known as Bedrock. Now, your leetle gran' nephew will be wiz us for two weeks, no? (opening a drawer) Here is ze application for him. An' mais oui, he weel participate in zee annual talent show, naturalment? Mrs. Slate takes the parchment application. Meanwhile the Headmistress looks appraisingly at Wilma and Betty.

dialogues.speaker: HEADMISTRESS
dialogues.text: An' your friends perhaps would like zum school applications for zere enfants?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SLATE
dialogues.text: (amused ) Them? Oh, Marie, really, you don't understand --

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (suddenly) That's right, you don't understand. My husband's business manager usually handles this sort of thing, but I don't mind. And to Wilma's astonishment, Betty takes one of the parchments.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I know Bam-Bam -- (correcting herself) -- pardonez-moi, 'Bem-Bem' will love attending your school and performing in the talent show. Thank you oh so much. She gives Mrs. Slate an even and controlled look, and sends some of it over in Wilma's direction as well. Wilma makes her choice, smiles tightly.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: Let me have one of those, too. For ma petite Pebbles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HEADMISTRESS
dialogues.text: Of course. Any friend of Madame Slate is a friend of mine. As Mrs. Slate reacts, we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're cruising along. Fred puffs on a cigar. Barney flips the pile of legal sized tablets in his lap. In the back seat are some boxes and bundles.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Gee, Fred, I don't believe it. Eight hours ago I didn't have a job and now look -- I got 1/2 of one percent of the after-taxes after-expenses net breakage profits on Fibrerock!

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Just be thankful I was there to go over the fine print. (full of himself) It's like I told you this morning -- There's something noble about a man digging in with his hands and doing an honest day's work. Once you file those dreams under 'old business' and put your nose to the plow, well, the world is your oyster. And was I right?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: No, Fred, you weren't. I didn't nose any grindstones and you didn't shoulder a wheel. We just hung out together and everything that happened was a total accident.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (after a moment) Details, Barney, details... (smiling) I just can't wait to see the girls' faces when we tell â€˜em the news...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls' frowns are a great contrast to their husbands' smiles. Wilma's looking at the school enrollment forms. Betty paces, looks at the clock. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: (seeing this) It's not like the boys to be so late.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Unless they were forced to go bowling again. Remember that time a burglar pointed a gun at them and said, 'go bowling right now'?

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: Betty, sometimes you're a little too gullible --

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Don't tell me. I still can't believe what I did today...

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: No kidding. (indicating the forms) Do you have any idea of what the enrollment fee is? And get this... it's non-refundable --

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I know, I know! I just couldn't stand that woman's attitude! But we had to find a new school anyway, and there we were... the next thing I knew, I was in over my head... but why did you jump in, too?

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: Oh, she was getting to me too with all that mastodon snort about her little nephew... and...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: And... if a friend can't help you do something stupid, who can? Betty smiles, touched. Then reality intrudes again.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: What do we tell the boys?

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: What's wrong with the truth? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: We put ourselves in debt so the kids can attend school with a family we can't stand?

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: (pause) Maybe we could rephrase it... Suddenly the door bursts open. Fred and Barney run in with candy and flowers.

dialogues.speaker: FRED AND BARNEY
dialogues.text: Surprise! Pause.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Flowers?

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: Rock candy? That's nice, but... why?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Why? Oh, me and Barn, we suddenly realized that we had a little spare change.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: (sotto) Not anymore you don't...

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (presenting flowers) Betty, these are for you. For sticking beside me during the tough times, and well... for making a little guy feel like he was ten feet tall.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Aw, Barney... I... I don't deserve these. I did something really stupid today.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Hey. Fred does something stupid every day and I still love him. Fred laughs good naturedly, grabs Barney in a headlock.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Noogy, noogy, ha, ha -- ! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: (observing this) Have you been drinking? In reply, Fred whips a bottle of champagne into view.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Ready when you are. (noticing the label) Hey, '1'... a good year. This confuses the girls even more.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: Fred, there's no easy way to say this so -- She closes her eyes, swings the enrollment forms over on the table so that Fred and Barney can read them. Fred and Barney look at them, look at each other... and yawn.

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING WILMA AND BETTY 76
dialogues.text: They can't believe this.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Boys... did you see... the dollar signs there at the bottom?

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: The non-refundable dollar signs?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Plenty more where that came from.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: We see your dollar signs, ladies... and... He tosses his stone contracts on top of the parchment ones with a THUD.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: . we raise them. Wilma and Betty look at each other, then at the contracts They blink, look again.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: Betty... these... these look... real -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Fred opens the champagne, which foams all over them. The girls squeal.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: You bet they're real, sweetheart. They're as real as... as... well, as real as -- (embracing the group) -- the best darn friends and neighbors in the whole world. Barney squeezes back.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Yeah. And nothing's ever gonna change that... right, Fred?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (emotionally) Right, pal o'mine. As they laugh and the girls slowly absorb the truth, we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sign proclaims this as "GRAND BEDROCK LODGE -- LOYAL ORDER OF WATER BUFFALO." The parking lot outside is full of vehicles. We hear the sound of a GAVEL BANGING...

dialogues.speaker: HERDMASTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Attention, fellow Water Buffaloes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The members are milling about the main room, schmoozing, drinking, kibitzing. All wear the furry and horned ceremonial Fez of the Buffalo. One wall of the lodge displays a big version of the lodge coat of arms (with the motto "Ackus Ackus Adackus" below) a trophy case holds a mind boggling display of various bowling trophies, balls and pins. At the lectern, the HERDMASTER (a mustachioed, inspirational type) bangs again for order.

dialogues.speaker: HERDMASTER
dialogues.text: Brothers, your attention! It quiets a bit. He clears his throat, raises his chin, and gives a strange mournful bellow. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HERDMASTER
dialogues.text: ("ritual" type tone) The herd is now called to the prairie. (holding fingers above ears) Antlers... up! The entire Lodge dutifully imitates this gesture.

dialogues.speaker: ENTIRE GROUP
dialogues.text: Ack-ack-a-dack!

dialogues.speaker: HERDMASTER
dialogues.text: (banging gavel) This meeting of the water Buffaloes is now in session. Sergeant-at-Arms, have we got any old business? Barney stands, acknowledges his friends and Lodge brothers.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Indeed we do, Brother Herdmaster. Tonight we are to hear speeches from prospective candidates for Lodge offices, such as good old Fred and some other guys.

dialogues.speaker: PILTDOWN 79
dialogues.text: Seated across the room with Pyrite and other cronies, he immediately leaps to his feet, paws the ground, and gives an eerie moan even stranger than the Herdmaster's earlier call to order.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE 80
dialogues.text: After the CRY ECHOES away:

dialogues.speaker: HERDMASTER
dialogues.text: Brother Piltdown: You have given the Cry of the Gelded Buffalo at the Poisoned Water Hole. Do you wish to file an objection?

dialogues.speaker: PILTDOWN
dialogues.text: You bet I do. How come Flintstone is 'good old Fred' and me and the other candidates are just 'some other guys'?

dialogues.speaker: PYRITE
dialogues.text: Yeah, how come? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (rising) My apologies, Brother Piltdown. Allow me to rephrase. Tonight we will hear speeches from a whole bunch of good old guys... (pause) plus the one and only Fred Flintstone! Cheers go up, which drown out Piltdown's renewed cry of the poisoned water hole. Fred moves towards the podium as the noise dies down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney moves to the wall, where he pulls a rolled up tapestry from a hiding place behind a plant. He tacks it to the wall, yanks a string. It unrolls. It's a big "VOTE FOR FRED FLINTSTONE" poster. Barney turns, gives Fred a "thumbs up," and as he does, Barney's hand brushes against a folded parchment in his pocket. Barney pushes his way through the seats, catches up to Fred and hands him the document. Fred takes it, continues up to the podium. There, the Herdmaster hands Fred the ceremonial hoof and antler, crossed over each other like a Pharaoh's badges of office. Fred does a Papal-like wave with these, sets them down, and unrolls the crib notes Barney gave him.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (reading, at first wooden, then confident ) Brother Buffaloes, honored Herdmaster, Junior Bucks and Apprentice Antlers, a great good evening to you all. Ahem. As you know, our organization has survived difficult times that have seen the extinction of such other lodges as the Order of Whooping Cranes and Brotherhood of Giant Sloths. But we here have come through the croo the crux...

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (hissing) -- crucible -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (grateful) -- crucible with our fur fluffy and our hooves unscathed. Now, the future holds many promises and many problems. As your next Herdmaster, I would bring to you the same determination, courage and -- if I may say so -- bold thinking that I have brought to the workplace. Thank you, and ack ack a-dack. Applause follows Fred's return to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: PILTDOWN AND PYRITE 82
dialogues.text: The only ones in their row not clapping, they scowl as Fred passes them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDEN as Barney propels a bowling ball (stone, of course) rumbling down the alley, sending pins flying. The Buffaloes cheer Barney's strike. We notice that most (if not all) of these Lodge members also work at the quarry.

dialogues.speaker: AUTOMATIC PIN SPOTTER 84
dialogues.text: It descends. It consists of a bent snout creature which "cranks" down a shelf with several monkeys on it. The monkeys grab the pins with their tails, straighten them up. Then the shelf cranks back up.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER END OF ALLEY 85
dialogues.text: Now it's Fred's turn. He trots up to the line, bowls... another strike! More cheers, AD LIB complaints, etc. The scorekeeper picks up hammer and chisel and fills out the last frame.

dialogues.speaker: LODGE MEMBER
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Fred.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Hey, when you're hot you're hot... boys, lemme buy a round of drinks for everyone.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Fred, but here at the lodge drinks are free. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: But the principle is the same, Barn. Don't forget that. Fred leads the group over to the bar. Piltdown and Pyrite come along with a shrug... why not, for a brew? Fred reaches --

dialogues.speaker: UNDER THE COUNTER 86
dialogues.text: where he pulls out a hook-beaked little LIZARD --

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE 87
dialogues.text: Fred uses this creature to open several beers.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (during this) Here you go, boys, nice and frosty...

dialogues.speaker: "BOTTLE OPENER" CREATURE, (LIZARD)
dialogues.text: (aside) Go ahead, laugh. If I had a good orthodontist, my life woulda been different... Fred tosses the "Opener" aside --

dialogues.speaker: UNDER THE COUNTER 88
dialogues.text: The critter bounces into the shelf, slides... when it re- covers, it realizes that its overbite has been straighten out by the impact. Very happy, it grabs a hat and coat, exits.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (raising drink) Well, here's to... He looks around, sees --

dialogues.speaker: "PHOTO" ON WALL 90
dialogues.text: It's actually "dots" chipped into a stone. It shows the young Fred, Barney and others gathered around soapbox racers. A banner reads "Junior Buffalo Day."  44.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Here's to the greatest bunch of lifelong Buffaloes a guy could dream of leading. (an obvious prompt) Anybody else got a toast...?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: "Here's to the Water Buffalo and their next Herdmaster... Fred'!

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Aw, gee, Barn... you shouldn't say that... (winking) . at least not till after next week's election!

dialogues.speaker: LODGE MEMBER
dialogues.text: Fred, what was all that stuff in your speech about the workplace? I thought the only decision you made there was how many lunches to eat -- Laughter. Fred accepts it good-naturedly, reaches into his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Well, Harry, it just so happens that old Fred is moving up in the world... Boys, you're looking at Mr. Slate's new partner.

dialogues.speaker: PILTDOWN
dialogues.text: You and Slate? Who are you kidding, Flintstone? The only partner you got is hanging over your belt. Pyrite laughs, a bit too much.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Prepare to eat those words, Piltdown.

dialogues.speaker: PILTDOWN
dialogues.text: -- If I don't, you will --

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (a tight smile) Gentlemen, my card -- He passes them out, and the others take them, curious --  92 93 94 45.

dialogues.speaker: CARD 92
dialogues.text: Of course it's a little stone tablet... but it does indeed say "SLATE CONSTRUCTION -- F. FLINTSTONE,

dialogues.speaker: LODGE MEMBERS
dialogues.text: (AD LIB, impressed) Hey, way ta go, Fred... Whoa, gonna switch from a hard hat to a top hat, Freddy boy...?

dialogues.speaker: PYRITE
dialogues.text: (examining the card) Ah, it's probably a phony... Saying this, he bites down on it... winces as a tooth cracks.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY 94
dialogues.text: tugs Fred's sleeve, pulls him close.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Gee, Fred, how come I didn't get any business cards?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Barney, it's all part of the plan. (to the others) Yes, boys, you see, I went up to my pal, Mister Slate and single- handedly made him an offer he couldn't refuse -- (Barney reacts to the "single-handedly" --)

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: -- 'Freddy boy,' he sez to me, "We gotta talk turkey -- '

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Fred, we gotta talk turkey --

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: That's right -- just like that --

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Fred -- ! Fred realizes Barney's got something on his mind.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Ah, excuse us, boys...  95 46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred pulls Barney into a quiet corridor. They stand near a trophy case. There's some bowling trophies here with a variety of names on them. (There's also trophies for "pie-eating contests" and "beer drinking chug-offs"; these have only Fred's name on them. )

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Fred... what's this single-handed stuff? I distinctly remember at least four hands and two of them were mine.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (lowered voice) Barney, we could tell everyone how you invented this Fibrerock stuff, how Slate and Lava found out about it by accident and all, but what would that be?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: The truth?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: This is big business, Barney. We can't start telling the truth, it'd create the wrong impression. Think about all the really big deals in history -- back to the beginning of recorded time. Barney knits his brow in thought for maybe three seconds.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: What do they all have in common? (as Barney is stumped) I'll tell you. A front man. A guy who's out in the public eye running the point, fighting the crowds... and meanwhile... back in the corner is the silent partner.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I never knew that.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: That's because the silent partner is always silent. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But while you're busy being silent -- (conspiratorially) -- all along you're the brains behind the operation and I'm the brains in front of the operation. I'm out here running the guts of the operation but you got a cut. It looks like my mind, but you're really behind.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I get it. I got the brains, but you just pretend to have them.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Attaboy! And a confident Fred shakes hands with an unsure "silent partner"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney comes out of his front door, heads toward the neighboring driveway and Fred's car. Betty comes out, calls to her husband.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Barney, wait a minute...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops, turns. Betty comes over and we see he's wear- ing a sports jacket and an abysmally-tied tie. Betty fixes the knot.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: There. That looks more like a captain of industry.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Betty. What would I do without you?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Hmm. Probably run off to the tropics with one of those executive secretaries. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Come on, Betty, it's only my first day. You have to have seniority to run off... She giggles, kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: FRED 98
dialogues.text: is at the car door, lunch pail in hand, when Wilma calls out to him.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: Fred! Wait a minute! There's something wrong with your lunch --

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: ("weighing it") Yeah... it does feel a little light... He returns to her, opens the pail, is surprised to find it's empty. Before he can comment, she smilingly presents him with a spanking new briefcase. '"F.F" is embossed on it in gold.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: Fit for a king... my king.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Aw, Wilma... lookit, it's got buckles, a strap, a lock -- He opens it. Inside is a huge drumstick and some ribs.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: -- Baby, you're the greatest.

dialogues.speaker: WILMA
dialogues.text: (kissing him) Good luck. (pause) Watch out for those... you know... hostile takeovers.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: I'm already taken. He moves to the car.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Ah, Mister Rubble, I presume? Of the Fibrerock Rubbles? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Yes, yes. Looking good, Mister Flintstone. I see you've recovered from that polo accident.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Yas, yas. The water was too deep and my horse drowned. They crack up at their own wit, drive off.

dialogues.speaker: SLATE QUARRY
dialogues.text: Lava's on the phone, very worried.

dialogues.speaker: LAVA
dialogues.text: Ivan, look, okay, so I bought too much on margin... everyone said glaciers were here to stay, I mean, who knew? Just leverage my shares in Atlantis dry goods and -- what? When did that happen? Piltdown enters, knocks on the open door.

dialogues.speaker: PILTDOWN
dialogues.text: Mister Lava, the armored car is here.

dialogues.speaker: LAVA
dialogues.text: Armored car...?

dialogues.speaker: PILTDOWN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Must be a fortune in coo-coo berries on that baby. You know, for that Fibrerock stuff of Flintstone and Rubble's. You gotta sign here for it.

dialogues.speaker: LAVA
dialogues.text: (into phone) I... I'll get back to you. Lava comes over, signs the form. Meanwhile he looks out the window at --

dialogues.speaker: ARMORED CAR 100
dialogues.text: The guards are unloading sacks of coo-coo berries.  50.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE 101
dialogues.text: Lava signs the form, meanwhile looking Piltdown up and down. Finally --

dialogues.speaker: LAVA
dialogues.text: Piltdown, this Fibrerock program is going to create a lot of changes around the plant. I want to make one more. You've been a wonderful thug and goon for me. Now, I'd like to expand your duties. I want you to become a provocateur.

dialogues.speaker: PILTDOWN
dialogues.text: Gee, Mister Lava, I donno. I kinda like girls myself.

dialogues.speaker: LAVA
dialogues.text: (patiently) What I mean, is, I'm going to use you to double-cross your Lodge and Union brothers, and make their lives a living hell.

dialogues.speaker: PILTDOWN
dialogues.text: Oh, okay.

dialogues.speaker: LAVA
dialogues.text: Good. You and your little pal will report directly to me and take orders only from me. (slapping him on the back) Now get out of here and start screwing your former friends and associates. Piltdown leaves, smiling. Lava rubs his chin, thoughtful.

dialogues.speaker: LAVA
dialogues.text: Coo-coo berries...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred and Barney appear in Fred's car, make a very quick turn into the quarry lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both duck down behind the wheel. A moment later, Feldspar's patrol car comes barrelling by. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Feldspar looks every which way, doesn't spot them.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (when he's gone) Gee, Fred, driving with you is better than an 'E' ticket at Magerock Mountain.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: (getting out) Gets the old adrenaline going, Barn. Us big executives, we need that kind of jolt to get the old wheels turning. Lava comes INTO VIEW, carrying an armload of plans.

dialogues.speaker: LAVA
dialogues.text: Flintstone! Rubble!

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Oh, hi, Mister Lava.

dialogues.speaker: LAVA
dialogues.text: Please, call me Jerry. Uncle -- I mean, Mister Slate told me to take you to your offices. If you'll follow me...? They move along. Fred notices a hotbed of activity nearby. Workers move scaffolding, animals labor.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Hey. What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: LAVA
dialogues.text: The Fibrerock assembly line. Unc -- Mister Slate's had a crew working on it all weekend. We're going to roll out the first sheets of Fibrerock by mid-week.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Yes, yes. Quick, dynamic entry into the marketplace. I approve.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: But, Fred, it's right where the employee basketball court used ta be -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Hey, you're right... (resigned) Big business is hell, Barney. Trust me... you'll get used to it.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I guess so. You already did. Lava leads them to a wood-sided trailer.

dialogues.speaker: LAVA
dialogues.text: Well, gentlemen, here you are. AS soon as you're settled, come over to the assembly line. We'll go over the Fibrerock formula before the first run. He goes off. Fred and Barney go --

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE TRAILER 104
dialogues.text: There're two tiny little desks at the far end, separated by a flimsy divider. The single window here looks out over the quarry scrap heap. (As we watch, somebody dumps a load of debris.) Threadbare furniture on a worn rug sits under a portrait of "Our Founder" (Slate).

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE 105
dialogues.text: Fred and Barney look at all this in turn. Pause. Then they whirl, give each other high-fives.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: All-right!

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Welcome to the top -- partner. And as they shake, we --

dialogues.speaker: ASSEMBLY LINE
dialogues.text: Now, accompanied by heroic "industrial"-type MUSIC, we see the Fibrerock assembly line in full operation. This cannot be described now with appropriate justice, but it involves a series of animal-powered conveyor belts, Rube Goldberg-like funnels, spouts and chutes, and all sorts of gadgets, gizmos, bells and whistles, to wit: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: At one end of the building, dino-powered dumpsters and lifters drop off all the ingredients; these get stomped/ chewed/bashed and otherwise reduced to powder, which is then (courtesy of some squirting Mastodans) mixed with water into a foam, which bubbles through a long sawmill- type trough and is held back by a gate. Meanwhile, we see a sample item (in this case, a stone sofa) as it is placed before two "goatasauruses" which butt heads and smash the sofa between the two halves of a clay mold. When the mold is opened and the sofa tossed aside, Barney appears and personally "aims" the foam trough at a funnel in the top of the mold. Pausing to "taste" the mix, he smiles, then shouts --

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Ready... aim... fibre! Barney pulls a rope which opens the trough. "Fibrefoam" pours into the mold.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLAY MOLD 107
dialogues.text: gets "winched" unpwards by monkeys, and then an alliga- torsaurus whaps it with its tail.

dialogues.speaker: BELOW 108
dialogues.text: Presto! A Fibrerock copy of the stone sofa drops neatly out of the mold, bounces lightly on the conveyor belt below! It sparkles with the tell-tale celadon-green shimmer of Fibrerock. As it chugs along, the process repeats, and soon a score of identical sofas is in view.

dialogues.speaker: END OF ASSEMBLY LINE 109
dialogues.text: as a beaming Fred watches, workers easily stack the Fibrerock sofas (often one-handed). Nearby, we see Fibrerock window frames, doors, chairs, etc.

dialogues.speaker: SLATE'S OFFICE BALCONY 110
dialogues.text: Slate and Lava watch the progress, dollar signs in their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SLATE QUARRY
dialogues.text: Fibrerock products are stacked up everywhere, stretching away like the inventory in Charles Foster Kane's warehouse. We see everything from Fibrerock bricks to Fibrerock table lamps to Fibrerock toilets. MUSIC OUT.  112 113 114 115 54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred and Barney, weary, approach each other, shake hands as they view the day's incredible output. Other weary, but proud workers gather around them: Mr. Slate is about to address them from his office balcony.

dialogues.speaker: SLATE
dialogues.text: Men, this is a proud day for Slate Construction. You have seen the first pieces of Fibrerock roll off the assembly line and into history... a history you are all part of... thanks to your very own fellow worker, Fred Flintstone!

dialogues.speaker: WORKERS
dialogues.text: They cheer Slate's remarks, pat Fred on the back.

dialogues.speaker: SLATE
